abstracts.cdata!:
The Tarbela Dam Project consists of an
            earth and rockfill dam across the Indus River, about six
            miles downstream from Tarbela Village. The dam, 485 feet
            high and about 9,000 feet long at its crest, will be flanked
            by two auxiliary embankments on the left abutment.
            Altogether, the three embankments will contain about 180
            million cubic yards of fill materials. The embankments are
            designed to impound 11.1 MAF of water which would provide
            initially 9.3 MAF of live storage. Two spillways with a
            combined discharge capacity of 1,670,000 cusecs will be
            provided at the left abutment to handle a flood inflow of
            2,127,000 cusecs, over twice the largest flood on record to
            date. Four tunnels, each 45 feet in diameter at the upstream
            end, are planned in the right abutment to divert the flow of
            the river during construction. Three tunnels will be
            designed to serve subsequently as power intakes and be
            equipped in such a way that each will be able to supply four
            generating units. The fourth tunnel is designed as a
            permanent irrigation water release outlet.
